Document Title: Thermal Compensation Method for Piezoresistive Pressure Transducer
Authors: R. d. S. Pereira; C. A. Cima
Author Affiliations: PPGEE, Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos, SÃ£o Leopoldo, Brazil; Cadence Design Systems, Belo Horizonte, Brazil
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Abstract: Piezoresistive pressure sensors are employed in a wide range of applications, but their output signal shows a substantial dependence on the working temperature. Usually, there is a need for an additional component to ensure a proper temperature-compensated signal for the sensors. In this article, we describe a method for the sensor thermal compensation that uses only the electrical signal produced by the pressure sensors themselves, without the need of additional measurements. The method proved to be effective while also ensuring a significant reduction in the measurement error.
Author Keywords: Measurement error;piezoresistive pressure sensor;piezoresistor;pressure sensor;thermal compensation
IEEE Terms: Temperature sensors;Temperature measurement;Piezoresistance;Bridge circuits;Mathematical model;Sensors;Pressure sensors
INSPEC Controlled Terms: compensation;measurement errors;piezoresistive devices;pressure measurement;pressure sensors;pressure transducers;temperature measurement;temperature sensors

Document Title: A Method for Measuring Torque of Squirrel-Cage Induction Motors Without Any Mechanical Sensor
Authors: W. L. Silva; A. M. N. Lima; A. Oliveira
Author Affiliations: Department of Education, Federal Institute of Bahia, Vitoria da Conquista, Brazil; Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Campina Grande, Campina Grande, Brazil; Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Bahia, Salvador, Brazil
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Abstract: This paper presents a method for estimating the torque of three-phase squirrel-cage induction motors. The method is not invasive, since it does not rely on mechanical sensors and only the measurement of the stator current is required. The slip and the rotational speed of the motor are estimated from the spectrogram of the stator current signal either in stationary or in nonstationary operating conditions. The torque is estimated from the ratio of the estimated slip and the rated one. A test platform equipped with a rotational speed sensor and a dc motor for measuring the torque of a three-phase induction motor fed by a pulsewidth-modulated voltage source inverter operating under scalar and vector control was implemented to verify the correctness of the proposed method. The validity of the proposed approach is demonstrated by the close agreement between the estimated values of the speed and torque obtained with the proposed method and the ones that are obtained from direct measurement.
Funding Information: Research Support Foundation of the State of Bahia; National Council for Scientific and Technological Development through the Development Project;
Author Keywords: Rotating machine measurements;signal processing;slot harmonics;spectral analysis;speed measurement;squirrel-cage induction motor;torque measurement.;Rotating machine measurements;signal processing;slot harmonics;spectral analysis;speed measurement;squirrel-cage induction motor;torque measurement
IEEE Terms: Induction motors;Torque;Rotors;Harmonic analysis;Velocity control;DC motors;Current measurement

Document Title: Modeling of a Resistive Voltage Divider by Rational Functions: Uncertainty Evaluation
Authors: L. A. A. de Souza; M. V. V. Pinto; M. B. Martins; A. C. S. Lima
Author Affiliations: Brazilian National Institute of Metrology, Quality and Technology, Duque de Caxias, Brazil; Brazilian National Institute of Metrology, Quality and Technology, Duque de Caxias, Brazil; Brazilian National Institute of Metrology, Quality and Technology, Duque de Caxias, Brazil; COPPE/UFRJ, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Abstract: This article describes the modeling of a resistive voltage divider (RVD) by rational functions using the vector fitting (VF) tool. The method is applied to ratio and phase displacement measurements over a wide frequency range. A Monte Carlo simulation-based sensitivity analysis was carried out to properly estimate the model uncertainty. The modeling tool proved to be an advantageous alternative with suitable adherence to the traced points, not exceeding a few parts in 106. Real and imaginary parts can be taken into account in the same fitting, preserving their correlation for the uncertainty estimation. Such a black-box approach can also help to estimate intermediate and above limit points since the transfer function is given by the tool.
Author Keywords: Modeling;Monte Carlo simulation;power quality (PQ);rational functions;sensitivity analysis;single tone approach;transducer;vector fitting (VF);voltage divider
IEEE Terms: Frequency measurement;Voltage measurement;Uncertainty;Impedance measurement;Electrical resistance measurement;Bridge circuits;Resistors
